name: Manchester Collegiate Church — Foundation Plans (1421)
description: Thomas de la Warre founded the Collegiate Church in 1421, transforming Manchester's parish church into a college of priests. Architectural plans of the original foundation exist.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: Find original/early architectural plans of the Collegiate Church.

1421: Thomas de la Warre obtains licence to refound St Mary's as a collegiate church.
Warden + fellows established 1422.
Perpendicular Gothic style — building we see today largely dates from this period.
The nave, choir, and chapter house from the 15th century survive.

Possible sources:
- Manchester Cathedral archives
- 'Manchester Cathedral: A History of the Collegiate Church and Cathedral' by Terry Wyke et al.
- RCHME (Royal Commission on Historical Monuments) survey
- Historic England listing: Grade I listed building
- Architectural drawings in John Rylands Library
- Chetham's Library (founded 1653, adjacent to the cathedral)

Chetham's Library itself (founded 1653) is the oldest public library in the English-speaking world.
Humphrey Chetham's Hospital (now Chetham's School of Music) built 1421 as clergy housing.
These buildings together form the oldest surviving complex in Manchester.
